NewsLines.HeadLine: Nailbiting German election night wrongfoots press

NewsLine.NewsLineText: GERMANY-NEWSPAPERS:Nailbiting German election night wrongfoots press

body.p: By Philip Blenkinsop

BERLIN, Sept 23 (Reuters) - German newspapers caught the sense of drama as the votes were counted in Sunday's agonisingly close general election, but fell down over the result, looking foolish on newsstands on Monday morning.
"Stoiber ahead of Schroeder," declared conservative-leaning Bild on its front page.
"(Conservative) union strongest party," read the headline on the front of the Frankfurter Allgemeine.
"The union the strongest in parliament," said the Sueddeutsche Zeitung above a picture of conservative leader Edmund Stoiber, beaming and with two thumbs up.

A thriller, a nailbiter, a night of nerves, all agreed. Yet several newspapers went to print when pollsters were still projecting a Stoiber victory and the prospect that neither a centre-left nor a centre-right coalition would be viable.

In fact, Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's Social Democrats won about 9,000 votes more than the conservatives and his future as Germany's leader was secured as support for his partners, the Greens, surged to 8.6 percent.
The Sueddeutsche made the link with the tight 2000 presidential battle in the United States between George W. Bush and Al Gore. Gore won more votes, but Bush took the prize.

"This election night stirs thoughts of America -- memories of the uncertain weeks after the last presidential election... Never before has it been so exciting, never before so dramatic -- and it will stay exciting," the Sueddeutsche said, predicting a rollercoaster ride of politics ahead.
Schroeder celebrated but did not hold aloft the papers, as U.S. President Harry Truman did with the "Dewey defeats Truman" headline of the Chicago Tribune in 1948.
The headline was immortalised in a photograph of Truman triumphantly showing the newspaper to a crowd after winning the race against New York Governor Thomas Dewey.
ONLINE AMENDMENTS

At least the online editions of Germany's dailies had made the necessary adjustments. Some suggested Schroeder's so-called "Red-Green" coalition faced an uncertain future given its much reduced majority of just nine seats.
"Shaky victory for Red-Green," said Bild on its Web site. It quoted Stoiber as saying: "By the year end I will be building a new government."
"Never before has a governing party suffered such losses after only four years. Gerhard Schroeder, the big winner in 1998, is now the big loser," Bild said.

The top-selling paper also described Greens' Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer as Schroeder's "saviour", saying his role in the outcome was ironic given the way in which Schroeder had pushed and cajoled the Greens over the past four years.
The Berliner Kurier repeated Schroeder's words "a majority is a majority" but added a warning in Schroeder's favoured footballing terms.
"Schroeder must keep the ball close to his feet. His majority is wafer thin," it said, adding Schroeder could hardly expect an initial honeymoon period as he did four years ago.
Most papers realised early that the ex-communist Party of Democratic Socialism faced humiliating defeat. It won just two seats and its loss helped the centre-left.

Few newspapers suggested the election represented a turn in the tide after a series of centre-right victories across Europe -- in Denmark, France, Ireland, the Netherlands, Norway and Portugal in the past year.

"Four years ago it seemed we were looking forward to the "Red-Green" decade, but now almost everywhere, there are centre-right coalitions. Only with an overwhelming win would a message have gone out from Germany," commentator Claus Leggewie said in the Sueddeutsche.
"An exciting election night, but four leaden years ahead?"
